comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content:
Harry Elionsky (d 1918), American distance swimmer, one of the famous US victims of the 1918 flu pandemic.

EDIT:  Not so much.  Keep reading below for more about Mr. Elionsky's non-death in the flu pandemic.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
Damaged Bain/LOC photo of Harry Elionsky in handcuffs and leg irons, preparing for a swim:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4526081924/in/photostream/]

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Could have been on October 5, 1913, when he attempted to swim with hands shackled and feet bound from the Battery (southern end of Manhattan Island) to Coney Island. See NYT of Oct 6, 1913 (second piece in this extract) query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B04E3D6163DE633A...

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Thank you  pennylrichardsca for giving us more complete information on swimmer Harry Elionsky’s name.  However, Elionsky appears not to have died in the influenza epidemic of 1918. A Boston Globe article (Oct. 14, 1918) states  that Elionsky had not died of influenza, as had been previously reported in an earlier article.  A 1921 New York Times article (June 28, 1921) says that Harry Elionsky announced that he was going to attempt a one hundred mile swim, so he was still alive then.  Swang,  as Elionsky made many stunt swims while shackled, it is hard to know if this is the one that occurred on Oct. 5, 1913.  So we will hold off on the more precise date for now.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Oh!  That's interesting--he's still listed in a lot of "famous victims of the 1918 flu" rolls.  He seems to serve as an example of how even the strongest were felled--because he was clearly a strong healthy guy!  Glad you corrected the error here.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:

Otto being untied after a 45-yard swim:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163748194/]

Claire Farry's hands [and feet] were tied, but she still made quite a splash:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4037488200/]

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: He didn't die during the flu epidemic, he was still swimming into the 1920's. The report of his death was premature and is still reported in error by two recent books. I started an entry in Wikipedia that has the correct information: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Elionsky I found his birth date from the World War I draft and will continue to look for his death.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The Unsinkable Harry Elionsky. Great sleuthing, Richard!
